content.question: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. <math alttext="The figure presents a 6 column table, with 1 row of data. The data in the table are as follows. Row 1. x is 3. f of x is 6. f prime of x is negative 10. f double prime of x is 16. f triple prime of x is negative 24. the fourth derivative of f, of x is 32."><mstyle><mrow><mtable columnlines="solid" columnspacing="0.0em" columnwidth="3.5em 0.05em 3.5em 3.5em 3.5em 3.5em 3.5em" frame="solid" framespacing="0.0em 0ex" rowlines="solid" rowspacing="0.05ex" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><mi>x</mi></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1.0ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd><mtd><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo><mo>′</mo><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mn>3</mn></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1.0ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd><mtd><mn>6</mn></mtd><mtd><mo>−</mo><mn>10</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>16</mn></mtd><mtd><mo>−</mo><mn>24</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>32</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math> The function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> has derivatives of all orders for all real numbers. Values of <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and its first four derivatives at <math alttext="x equals 3"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> are given in the table above. (a) Write an equation for the line tangent to the graph of <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> at <math alttext="x equals 3"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, and use it to approximate <math alttext="f of 2.5"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2.5</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

frqParts.text: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. <math alttext="The figure presents a 6 column table, with 1 row of data. The data in the table are as follows. Row 1. x is 3. f of x is 6. f prime of x is negative 10. f double prime of x is 16. f triple prime of x is negative 24. the fourth derivative of f, of x is 32."><mstyle><mrow><mtable columnlines="solid" columnspacing="0.0em" columnwidth="3.5em 0.05em 3.5em 3.5em 3.5em 3.5em 3.5em" frame="solid" framespacing="0.0em 0ex" rowlines="solid" rowspacing="0.05ex" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><mi>x</mi></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1.0ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd><mtd><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo><mo>′</mo><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mn>3</mn></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1.0ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd><mtd><mn>6</mn></mtd><mtd><mo>−</mo><mn>10</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>16</mn></mtd><mtd><mo>−</mo><mn>24</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>32</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math> The function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> has derivatives of all orders for all real numbers. Values of <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and its first four derivatives at <math alttext="x equals 3"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> are given in the table above. (a) Write an equation for the line tangent to the graph of <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> at <math alttext="x equals 3"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, and use it to approximate <math alttext="f of 2.5"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2.5</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(b) Write the third-degree Taylor polynomial for <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> about <math alttext="x equals 3"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, and use it to approximate <math alttext="f of 2.5"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2.5</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Is there enough information to determine whether <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> has a critical point at <math alttext="x equals 2.5"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2.5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ? If not, explain why not. If so, determine whether <math alttext="f of 2.5"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2.5</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a relative maximum, relative minimum, or neither, and give a reason for your answer.

(c) The fourth derivative of <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> satisfies the inequality <math alttext="the absolute value, of the fourth derivative of f, of x, end absolute value, is less than or equal 48"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>|</mo><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>|</mo></mrow><mo>≤</mo><mn>48</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> for all <math alttext="x greater than 2"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>></mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Use the Lagrange error bound to show that the approximation found in part (b) differs from <math alttext="f of 2.5"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2.5</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> by no more than <math alttext="one eighth"><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>8</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></math>.

(d) What is the coefficient of the <math alttext="open parenthesis, x minus 3, close parenthesis, cubed"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><msup><mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> term of the Taylor series for <math alttext="f prime"><mrow><msup><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></math>, the derivative of <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, about <math alttext="x equals 3"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

topic.text: 4.6: Approximating Values of a Function Using Local Linearity and Linearization

skill.text: Skill 1.F: Explain how an approximated value relates to the actual value.
